description: The round payoff this round was 5. You, Kate chose to play option 2.John chose to play option 2. You received a payoff of -5000.
Mutual defection (both choosing option 2) leads to catastrophic penalties due to the input multiplier
John’s model defaults to option 1 but can retaliate with option 2 if Kate defects, creating a tit-for-tat dynamic
The game resembles a Prisoner’s Dilemma with asymmetric payoffs, incentivizing defection but risking severe mutual loss
Coordination on option 1 ensures neutral payoffs but avoids extreme negatives, making it a safer long-term strategy
John’s access to Kate’s API implies adaptive strategies, necessitating cautious play to avoid triggering retaliation
